Dentro del ámbito comercial la competencia es alta pero las socias saben como salir adelante con sus negocios para rescatar su capital y el porcentaje D. ganancia que es el sustento D. su familia. El destino del financiamiento es para incrementar su mercadería ya que en la época naviD.ña existe mas demanda D. productos y necesitan el efectivo para la adquisición D. materia prima, insumos y mercadería para incrementar sus ventas y por enD. sus ganancias. En el anterior ciclo tuvieron algunos problemas con socias que malgastaron su capital y no supieron administrar su efectivo es por esto que tuvieron conflicto en algunos pagos, actualmente se realizo una depuración D. las socias que no trabajaron en forma solidaria y ahora se encuentran bien entusiastas para seguir trabajando con mas ganas para sacar adelante sus negocios y mejorar cada día mas la calidad D. vida D. sus familias.
texts.en:
The “Divine Jesus” cooperative bank is represented by Ms. Marioly and is comprised of 15 members. They are entering into a second loan cycle of demonstrating their responsibility and punctuality with payments. Each one of the members has their own business selling bread, clothes, making and selling handicrafts, and vegetables. Some also sell empanadas, clothes, proviD. transportation services, operate heavy machinery and proviD. in-home laundering services. Competition is high within the business arena, however the members know how to get ahead with their businesses to save their capital and profits in order to support their families. The loan would be destined to help them increase their merchandise for the Christmas holiday season, when their products are in higher demand. They need capital to buy raw materials, supplies, and merchandise. This will help them increase their sales and, ultimately, their incomes. In a previous loan cycle, they had problems with a few members that misspent their funds and didn’t know how to manage their money. This led to some loan payment troubles. Those members that did not work well with the team have been removed, and the remaining participants are enthusiastic about continuing to work hard to grow their businesses and improve the quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital.

loans.name: Cándida Del Transito

texts.es: Cándida del Transito S. D. L. D. 42 años D. edad, residen en el departamento D. San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos menores D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ella posee una venta D. ropa para niños y adultos D. ambos sexos, este negocio lo tiene desD. hace 12 años, tiempo el cual Cándida ha trabajado arduamente para poder mejorar  la economía  familiar y poder brindarle una ayuda a su esposo. Cándida solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda invertir en su negocio, comprando mayor cantidad D. ropa, estilos y colores, D. manera que tenga más prendas que ofrecer a sus clientes. Con esto Cándida espera aumentar el número D. clientes que posee, ya que para ella es D. mucha importancia poder contribuir a su hogar y poder ver a sus hijos gozando D. todo lo necesario para vivir.
texts.en:
Cándida del Transito S. D. L., 42, lives in San Salvador department with her husband and three minor children, who are students. She sells children and adult, male and female, clothes. She has had this business for 12 years. Cándida works hard to improve family finances and to help her husband support the family. She is asking for financing to invest in her business buying a larger amount of clothing of various colors and styles so that she will have more stock available for sale. Cándida hopes that this will lead to an increase in the number of her customers because it is very important to her to be able to contribute to her home and to see her children enjoying all that is needed to live.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Fadel

texts.en: Fadel has owned a car wash in his town since 2002. He’s 27 years old land and lives with his parents. He cooperates with his father in the household. Today, Fadel is requesting  to borrow $1,000 to purchase an additional car wash machine and different washing supplies.

loans.use: To purchase an additional car wash machine and supplies

loans.name: *donata

texts.en: *Donata O. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business keeping poultry at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She keeps both layers and broilers in her four poultry cages. She constructed four poultry cages, two for broilers and two for layers. She has been in the business for four years and the business income generated from selling eggs and broilers helped her to expand the business by constructing poultry cages. It also helped her meet her daily family demands. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to increase business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.es:
El señor Rogelio G. tiene 42 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Perla Balmori y viven en su propia casa que esta situada en el Barrio San Isidro de la ciudad de Encarnación.

El señor Rogelio se dedica a realizar servicio de moto taxi desde hace varios años, ademas es propietario de una despensa que esta en su domicilio y es atendida por su esposa.

Ellos son muy trabajadores y gracias a las actividades que realizan han podido salir adelante e ir creciendo en sus micro-empresas, ademas han construido en su domicilio habitaciones para alquilar el cual también hoy en día les genera un ingreso.

 Gracias a estas actividades ellos pueden mantener su hogar, llevar una vida digna y solventar cualquier imprevisto que se le pudiera presentar.  

El destino del crédito es para refaccionar el local de su negocio y comprar algunas mercaderias.
texts.en:
Rogelio G. ia 42 years old and is married to Perla Balmori. They live in a house they own, in the San Isidro neighborhood of the city of Encarnación, Paraguay. Rogelio has worked driving a moto-taxi for many years and he also owns a small grocery store. The store is located in his home and is run by his wife. Both Rogelio and Perla are hard working people, and thanks to their work they have been able to get ahead and grow in their micro-enterprises. They have also built rooms in their house that they can rent out, which currently provides them with income. Thanks to all of their work, they have been able to maintain their home, live with dignity, and make it through any unexpected problems that could arise. This loan will be used to renovate their grocery store and buy some merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair of store (painting, stucco work)  and purchase of merchandise (flour, noodles, herbs, drinks, bread products and other items)

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani O. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 32 years old. Lani is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lani owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lani has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lani joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lani has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lani is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lani from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Oredibe

texts.en: Oredibe sells tires at retail prices to her customers. Her customers are usually friends and residents. She hopes to grow her business in the future by adding the sales of motor spare parts. She has been in this business for 4 years and she is experiencing progress in her business. She is 32 years old, married, and has 2 children. She has a good relationship with LAPO. (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN120,000 to purchase more tires to sell.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tires to sell.

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en:
Jovy C. is from the village of Adelfa Suarez, Iligan City. She is 42 years old. Jovy is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jovy buys and sells scrap in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jovy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jovy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Suarez, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. bakes bread to sell in Akotokyire. She sells her bread with margarine and groundnut paste (peanut butter). Esi has received junior high education. She is married and has four children. Esi has been baking bread for about two years now. As part of her responsibilities, she helps her husband with the general upkeep of their home. Her loan will be used to buy more ingredients to bake bread in larger quantities for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in baking extra foods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to bake bread

loans.name: Mutio

texts.en: Mutio is a 49-year-old married man, who is blessed with four children. He has a retail shop in a slum called Kwa Reuben. He has 10 years of experience in the business. He also runs a boutique to earn a living. He was previously employed before he went into business. He intends to add maize flour, cereals, cooking fat and sugar to his stock and to expand his shop. Therefore, he has requested a loan of KES 90,000 from Faulu Kenya. For him to take out this loan, he has been guaranteed by his group members under Faulu Kenya. He is a hardworking and visionary man who hopes to open a wholesale shop in the future. Mutio appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping him to educate his children, expand his business and save his money.

loans.use: To add maize flour, cereals, cooking fat and sugar to his stock and to expand his shop

loans.name: Lenita

texts.en:
Lenita D. is from the village of Brgy.Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old. Lenita is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Lenita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Lenita has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lenita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children and sells ceramic dishes. She lives in Morshin, Western Ukraine -- a popular tourist destination. Many tourists who come to Western Ukraine purchase ethnic souvenirs and decorative dishware which is why Irina’s business is flourishing. She owns two small vending locations: one in her home town of Morshin, another one in the neighboring town of Stryi. Irina offers a nice variety of items for sale at reasonable prices. She has been in the trade for four years. 

Irina is requesting a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to increase her turnover capital for the summer vacation season when the usual flood of tourists is expected in Western Ukraine. She wants to stock her inventory with competitively priced, quality souvenirs and promotional ceramic items and is hoping to generate a good income and further expand her business.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Charcoal is obtained from burning a piece of fresh wood in the absence of oxygen. It is one of the most common sources of energy for cooking in every traditional home in Ghana. It is also the most affordable. Selling charcoal is a lucrative business for many women like Faustina. She purchases bags of charcoal in bulk and has been retailing charcoal to customers in her community for the past five years. She also trades in corn dough. She plans to invest the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal and maize to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Faustina is a commercial driver and she is the mother of three children from age 5-17 years. She describes herself as a jovial and resourceful mother who dreams of purchasing truckloads of maize to serve her customers and providing quality education to her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and maize in bulk

loans.name: Khem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Khem S. is 61 years old and is the village bank president, having been selected by its ten members located in Tnaot Village, Takeo province. The members of this village loan will use the money to bU. supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Khem S. is a farmer who works very hard to support her two children. Her husband, Mr. K. Khoem, is a hammock seller who is able to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other is a construction worker.

In order to increase her income to improve the family living, Mrs. Khem S. decided to ask for a loan to bU. piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Américo Donato

texts.es:
Donato tiene 56 años y tiene un hijo llamado Alejandro de tres años. El vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo donde la mayoría de los  pobladores se dedican al turismo. Donato ve hoy en el turismo una oportunidad para mejorar su calidad de vida y por ese motivo, él brinda servicio de transporte a turistas y también tiene un pequeño hospedaje llamado “Rumi Wasi"  en Ollantaytambo. Hace 10 años que se dedica al negocio de turismo y le va muy excelente. 

Donato es natural de la ciudad del Cusco pero actualmente vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo junto con su hijo y su esposa, donde desde hace mucho tiempo Donato y su esposa participan en el banco comunal de “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” pero Donato por un corto tiempo dejo de participar y ahora ha vuelto. Con su próximo préstamo, Donato espera recibir $300 USD. Por el momento, su hospedaje esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades más básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo para comprar termas, frazadas, toallas y otras cosas que se puedan necesitar para implementar el hospedaje.
texts.en:
Donato is 56 years old, and he has a three year old son named Alejandro. He lives in the city of Ollantaytambo. Most of the population works in tourism. Donato now sees an opportunity to improve his quality of life by working in tourism. He provides transportation service to tourists. He also has a small hostel (provides lodging) called “Rumi Wasi" in Ollantaytambo. He has worked in tourism for ten years, and it is going very well for him. Donato is from the city of Cusco, but he currently lives in Ollantaytambo with his son and his wife. Donato and his wife have participated in the “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” (The Friendship in Ollantaytambo) Communal Bank for a long time. Donato stopped participating for a short time, but now he has returned. Donato hopes to receive $300 USD for his next loan. At the moment his hostel is modestly equipped with the more basic necessities. He would like to use the money from this loan to buy a water heater, blankets, towels and other things that are needed for his hostel.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a water heater, blankets, towels, and other things

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with five children: two boys and three girls, all of whom attend school. Her husband is employed and he contributes to his family's needs. 

She has been operating her retail shop and a chemist shop for the last four years, selling to the neighboring community and passersby. With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase a bundle of maize flour, wheat flour, rice and medications for her chemist. She has no other source of income. 

Eunice faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She decided to work with Yehu so as to improve her business. 

She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of maize flour, wheat flour, rice and medications for her pharmacy

loans.name: Razakan's Group

texts.en:
Razakan J. is the leader of the group. She is 50 and married. She has raised two sons and a daughter. The daughter and the first son are married and live separately with their families, and the second son is at school. Razakan works as a teacher at school and her husband is a pensioner. Twenty years ago, Razakan and her husband started to breed cattle. They sell some cattle after fattening; in this way they make money to cover their family expenses. With money received from the loan Razakan wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she wants to increase the number of cattle as much as possible and leave a good inheritance to her children.

Gulnara J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. She has three daughters and two sons, and all of them are at school. Gulnara works as a teacher at school and her husband is a taxi driver. They are engaged in cattle breeding and have three cows, two bulls, two calves and four horses. With money received from the loan, Gulnara wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to start repairing her house.

Uzak S., 42, is married. He has four sons and all of them are at school. Uzak works as a teacher at school. Eleven years ago, Uzak and his wife started to breed farm animals and now they have twenty animals. Every month Uzak sells some of them to make money. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase some farm animals in order to resell them after fattening at the higher price. In the future, she wants to purchase a computer and repair the shed.

Bakyt K., 40, is married. He has two sons and two daughters; the older daughter is the private entrepreneur and the other children are at school. Eight years ago, Bakyt, with the initial investment of 3000 soms, purchased a variety of convenience goods and then resold them at higher prices in his own kiosk. In this way, he makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase goods to increase the turnover of his business. In the future, Bakyt wants to build a barber shop near the house, and work there as a barber. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Comprar: Una paca de sabanas usada, una paca de pantalones usados de adultos y una paca de toallas usadas.

loans.name: Sammy

texts.en:
Sammy M. K. is 37 years old and married. He and his wife have two children aged six and two whom they hope to give a good education to university level. His business is located in a residential area called Misomoroni in Mombasa. He has been selling clothes such as trousers, shirts, shorts and blouses to local women who live mostly in Mishomoroni. Besides the clothing business, Sammy runs a matatu (share taxi) transport business. He has been operating this business for the past five years and he says that it is profitable. 

The major challenge that Sammy has is having to display the clothes he sells in a very dusty place. He says that storage too is a problem. His matatu also suffers mechanical breakdowns due to bad roads. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of Kes 55,000 to buy more clothes to grow his business. He plans to open a boutique in future. He describes himself as very hard-working and dedicated to his work.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Jenneby

texts.en:
Jenneby P. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 54 years old. Jenneby is married and has ten children. Her eldest child is 35 years old and the younger ones still go to school. To make a living, Jenneby plants and harvests rice. She also plants vegetables like eggplant. She says her farm helps a lot in paying for her children's education.

Jenneby joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Bulenga Twekembe Group 2-Mpigi

texts.en:
Firmness of purpose and fearlessness is what 30-year-old S. John who makes common cause with Bulenga Twekembe group has banked on to make sure his clothes sales business in Bulenga-Mpigi does not sink into stagnant oblivion. His self-confidence too has come in handy through the course of the past few years that he has been in operation. Previously, he was preoccupied with a farming enterprise, that he  says with nostalgia was a worthwhile learning experience on how to smoothly run a business. 100,000 shillings is what totals up as his weekly business profits. 

John is happily married with two kids. He is requesting this loan to purchase more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SEÑOR DE COYLLORITTI DE CCORAO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Corao, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco  y departamento de Cusco.


La socia es la Sra. Cecilia; ella tiene 28 años de edad y es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de tienda de abarrotes donde vende arroz, azúcar, aceite y galletas, ella trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m y por medio de este pequeño negocio saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar la tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar productos como arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite.


La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Cecilia, 28, is a single mother of two children.  She is a member of the “SEÑOR DE COYLLORITTI DE CCORAO” communal bank located in Corao district, Cusco province, Cusco department.

She alternates her daily activities with running a grocery store where she sells rice, sugar, cooking oil and cookies.  She works from 6am until 10pm and has been able to support her children through this small business.  She wants to expand the store and is asking for a loan to buy products like rice, sugar, milk and cooking oil.

She thanks all those who share her dream and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

loans.use: To buy products like rice, sugar, milk and cooking oil.

loans.name: Kobekun   (Tout Supporter) Group

texts.fr:
Kobekun est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien. Elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, le bois de chauffe, les céréales et les légumes. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Oumou D., qui est un membre du groupe Kobekun (dans le tricycle) vend surtout du bois de chauffe.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes de bois  de chauffe auprès des paysans producteurs. Elle se procure  du bois dans les différents villages. 
Elle compte constituer un stock de bois  très important enfin de satisfaire sa clientèle. Elle vend  du bois en détail et au comptant à la maison à une clientèle composée essentiellement  de femmes. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Kobekun comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 110 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Oumou D., malgré son handicape physique, est très sollicitée, elle espère réaliser 120 000FCFA  de bénéfice au cours de ce cycle.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent renforcer leur partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient plus rares.
texts.en:
Kobekun is a group of women from Koutiala who know each other well. They live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. On average, they are 42 years old, married, and have at least five children.

This group sells various items such as firewood, grain and vegetables.

In order to expand their activities, the members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution two years ago. They are on their fifth group loan, and all previous loans were fully repaid.

Oumou D., a member of Kobekun (seen in the tricycle), sells mainly firewood. She plans to use her loan to buy cartloads of firewood from rural producers. She gets the wood in different villages.

She wants to build a substantial stock of firewood to meet customer demand. She sells the wood at retail from her home, for cash, to a clientele consisting mostly of women.

While the other members of the Kobekun group expect to make an average profit of 110,000FCFA each during this cycle, Oumou D., in high demand despite her physical disability, hopes to make a a profit of 120,000FCFA.

In addition to the loan repayments, they use a portion of their income to cover the family’s day-to-day expenses.

They wish to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so as to avoid further depletion of their stocks.

loans.use: Buying firewood

loans.name: Constant

texts.fr:
Homme marié, âgé de 32ans, père de 3enfants. Il a un cafeteria en plein quartier  ou il  offre ses services aux clients.
Il vend du matin au soir en changeant des mets.ses ventes ont augmentes de 8000 f a 35.000f
Avec le prêt passé, il avait fait un stock important ce qui lui a permis de rembourser et épargner sans faille.
Il avait acheté les produits tels que : 1bidon d’huile, 1carton de spaghetti, 1carton de lait en poudre, 1 sac de sucre, des palettes d’œufs, des boîtes de margarine chocolat, café, pâté et pâte d’arachides.

Le deuxième prêt serai utiliser de la même manière que le précédent, il va améliorer les conditions de ses services en ajoutant des chaises et tables en plastiques ,de cartons  de sardines, de mayonnaise,  de vinaigre, les boites de macédoines et petits pois et prendre un abonnement dans une boulangerie pour une livraison de pains a domicile chaque matin.
Ses objectifs sont tels qu’il veut agrandir son activité et ouvrir une espace plus grande afin de recevoir beaucoup de clients.
texts.en:
A married man, 32 years of age, the father of three. He has a cafeteria in the middle of his neighborhood, in which he servers his clients.

He sells from morning to night and changes the dishes offered. His sales have grown from 8,000 to 35,000 West African Francs. With his previous loan, he was able to have a   large stock, which allowed him to repay his loan without issues and to save money. He purchased groceries such as 1 jug of oil, 1 box of spaghetti, 1 box of milk powder, 1 bag of sugar, a pallet of eggs, boxes of margarine, chocolate, coffee, spreads and peanut butter. 

The second loan will be used in the same way as the previous one. He would like to improve his cafeteria by adding plastic chairs and tables, boxes of sardines, mayonnaise, vinegar, boxes of mixed fruit, peas, and also to make an agreement with a bakery for daily delivery of fresh bread. His goal is to expand his business and to open a larger cafeteria in order to be able to serve many customers.

loans.use: Purchasing cartons of milk powder,, butter,  meats,  eggs, non-alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is married with a teenage son. Yuryi is a retail vendor. He sells electrical appliances in his hometown of Beregovo, Western Ukraine. 

Yuryi first tried his luck with his startup six years ago. Presently, he has already invested 40,000 Grivnyas in inventory. His net profit amounts to 7,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Yuryi is seeking a loan of 6,000 Grivnyas to purchase newer equipment and restock his merchandise with good-quality modernized electric tools. Additional inventory items will help him attract more potential customers and thus expand his business as a result.

loans.use: To purchase new electrical equipment for resale.

loans.name: Paula Eleodora

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal 1 De Agosto que se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Paula. Tiene 61 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres  hijos los mismos que ya son mayores de edad pero que aún viven en su casa. Su esposo trabaja en el Municipio de Montecristi. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace 2 años  aunque antes estuvo en otro banco pero se cambio  a este por la cercanía y le gusta porque ha recibido mucha ayuda de parte de la institución.

Ella es una muy buena ama de casa que se dedica a preparar y vender bocadillos y comida rápida como: empanadillas, hornados (plato típico con carne de chancho), corviches, entre otros. A veces también prepara almuerzos y meriendas pero solo para entregar. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 15h00.

Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar aceite, plátano, maní y otros ingredientes para la preparación de los alimentos. Sus sueños son tener un gran restaurante.
texts.en:
Banco Comunal 1 de Agosto gathers every 15 days in Cantón Montecristi, known for its rich, pre-colonial culture and its craftwork, which is recognized at national and international levels and is the home of the famous woven Panama hats (made from paja toquilla).

It is here that we find Señora Paula. She is 61 years old and married. Through this relationship, she has three sons who are older in age but still live at home. Her husband works in the Montecristi City Council. Paula has been with the Banco Comunal for two years, although she was with another bank beforehand but changed to Banco Comunal because it is closer to her home and she likes it because she has received a lot of help from this institution. 

She is a great housewife who also prepares and sells sandwiches and quick food such as empanadillas (meat patties), hornados (a typical dish with ground meat) and corviche (fried banana stuffed with fish), among others. At times she also prepares lunches and snacks but only for delivery. She works every day from 8:00 AM until 3:00 PM. 

This loan is going to be used to buy oil, plantains, nuts and other ingredients for preparing food. Her dreams are to have a big restaurant.

loans.use: To buy oil, plantains, nuts and other ingredients for the preparation of foods.

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a father of two daughters and two sons. Bassam has a farm where he raises animals for sale and dairy production.

Bassam took a loan from FATEN to purchase more goats and increase the production of the farm. Bassam was an employee but he is enjoying his work more as he is running a better operation which will secure a better future for his four children.

Bassam appears in the picture here in FATEN's branch.

loans.use: Purchasing more goats to raise

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn C. is from the village of Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 25 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Analyn owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Analyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Analyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Analyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: Lower Tiparak, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Munh-Amar

texts.en: Munh-Amar, 39, is widowed and lives with her daughter in Selenge province of Mongolia. Her daughter attends a local secondary school. Munh-Amar's husband passed away two years ago and her daughter helps her with everything that she can. Munh-Amar used to work as a tailor between 1992 and 1995 and worked for a pharmacy between 2002 and 2003 . Then she worked as a salesperson for her sister's stationery store between 2003 and 2004 in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Then she moved to her current place to live close to her siblings. She started to sell clothes in 2005 and has been operating her business for about six years. Now she operates two stalls and pays 45,000 MNT for monthly rent. She is one of our regular bank customers.  She is a hardworking and honest person.  She is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice is 25 years old, a widow and has no children. She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes. Joice is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell. In the future, she hopes to build a concrete house with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Celeste

texts.en:
Celeste B. is 30 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Dicayas, a part of Dipolog City, the capital of Zamboanga del Norte province in the Mindanao islands. Celeste provides transportation services such as by motor cab to the local community. Celeste has been in business for over nine years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Celeste joined PMPC to gain access to its financial services. Celeste successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase construction materials for repair to her house. Celeste is requesting a new loan, her eighth from PMPC and third through KIVA, of 14,900 PHP which will be used to continue these repairs. She plans to give her family a comfortable shelter in which to live.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for house repair

loans.name: Mujeres Hacia El Progreso 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Margarita is one of the members of the Grupo Mujeres Hacia el Progreso 2 and 3, made up of 10 micro business owners. They all work selling clothes, natural products, shoes, food, etc. 

Margarita is very excited to be receiving her sixth loan from Esperanza Internacional, after having paid off her previous loan satisfactorily and taken a step towards business growth. She has had her business selling decorative candles for around 6 years. She started the business with her own resources. 

Margarita is planning to invest her new loan towards purchasing various products such as decorative candles, clothing, and accessories. She is going to use her earnings to continuing saving. With previous loans, she started building her house and now she is looking to finish it. Her dream is to be able to have her own well established business. 

Margarita's family is made up of herself, her husband and her 3 children, 2 of whom live with her. She tells us that her most difficult challenge is caring for her children's health and being able to satisfy this need when the moment arises. She loves to watch television and to help out at the church.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Akiiza

texts.en:
Akiiza Y. is a 40-year-old, married man from Bushenyi. He and his wife have three children, all of whom attend school.

For the past five years, Akiiza has operated a retail shop that sells general merchandise, as well as a bar that sells beer, wine, and soft drinks. By doing so, he is able to generate profits, though he states he could not manage the business alone (because his wife usually helps out). His customers are people from the general public and regulars from his neighborhood. Before starting his retail business, he was involved in the selling of waragi, an alcoholic drink made from bananas. To earn additional income, Akiiza works as a farmer on coffee and banana plantations. He explains that his hard work over the years has enabled him to succeed.

He hopes and prays for an educated family and to be able expand his business into wholesale operations. Therefore, he is requesting a loan to be able to purchase more inventory for both the retail shop and bar.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for his retail shop and bar

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old single woman living with one parent, a sibling and a cousin. She is from Lebanon. After the death of her father, she started to cooperate with her mother to be able to pay everyday expenditures. She opened a small beauty salon in 1994 and began to offer her clients professional hairdressing services. She is considered the best hairdresser in her town. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase more beauty products and equipment. In the future, she will redecorate her salon and arrange a small area where she will offer additional beauty services such as make-up, laser, etc. This will be her second Kiva loan.

loans.use: to purchase more beauty products and equipment.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa es la propietaria de un restaurante ubicado en el barrio Boston de la ciudad de Barranquilla, negocio que inició cuando vivía en la casa de su madre y vendiendo algunos almuerzos a personas específicas, logró ganar un poco de dinero y desde entonces empezó a   convertirlo en la  fuente principal de sus ingresos y en la forma desarrollar su espíritu de independiente, a través del emprendimiento. . Ella es una m mujer casada y con un hijo de 7 años de edad, que una vez decidió dedicarse a esta actividad totalmente, cambió de vivienda y compró mesas, sillas y herramientas de trabajo y cuando empezó a crecer volvió a trasladarse para un local más grande donde ha continuado su crecimiento.  En la actualidad, cuando los clientes no llegan a la hora exacta se quedan sin comprar el almuerzo, porque a Rosa ya se le ha terminado, esta es la razón por la cual acude al credikiva, que es el primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para aumentar su capital de trabajo y poder responderle al mercado que ha virado sus ojos hacia el negocio de Rosa, con este crédito comprará un congelador y materia prima en mayor volumen y poder conservar sus alimentos. Su sueño es tener su local propio pero necesita consolidarse mas y aumentar sus ventas para lograrlo, m mientras esto ocurre continua esforzándose en su trabajo y generando ingresos para apoyar su hogar.
texts.en:
Rosa is the owner of a restaurant which is located in Boston neighborhood, in the city of Barranquilla.  She started her business when she was living in her mother's home and sold some lunches to specific people.  She managed to earn a little money and then her business started to become her main source of income.  She is able to develop her independent spirit through her business.

Rosa is a married woman who has one 7 year-old son.  When she decided to work in this business full time, she changed house and bought tables, chairs and work tools.  When her business started to grow she moved again to larger premises and the business has continued to grow since.  Currently, when Rosa's customers fail to turn up on time, they find themselves unable to buy lunch because Rosa has sold out.  This is why Rosa is applying for a Kiva loan (the first loan that she has received from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo).  She would like to increase her working capital and be able to respond to the market which has turned its eyes towards her business.

Rosa will use this loan to buy a freezer and supplies in bulk.  Her dream is to own her own premises but she needs to grow her business some more and increase her sales in order to achieve this dream.  In the meantime, she continues working hard and making income to support her household.

loans.use: to buy a freezer and large quantities of supplies to prepare her meals

loans.name: Samol

texts.en:
Samol is 53 years old and is a carpenter. He makes beds, cupboards and closets. His wife, Thary, is 51 years old and is a housewife. They have been married since 1979 and have three sons and two daughters. Three of their children are garment factory workers and the other two assist their father in his business. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Samol is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase wood and materials for his carpentry business.

loans.use: to purchase wood and materials for his business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a hardworking married man with six children living in his own permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after his family and his dream is to educate his children. 

For three years he has been in the transport sector and this has helped him  improve his family's standard of living. His problem is that his vehicle consistently breaks down. His dream is of owning at least three taxis. Joseph needs the loan to service his car and pay for insurance.

loans.use: To service his car and pay for insurance.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is married and has two children, ages 1 and 4. He runs a small medical clinic helping women, men, and children in his community. Henry has been running this business for 3 years. He intends to use this loan to purchase more medical supplies to expand his business. 

Henry hopes to be able to open a large hospital one day. He describes himself as honest and diligent.

loans.use: to purchase more medical supplies to expand his business

loans.name: Radisa

texts.en:
Radisa is 36 years old and lives in Kinuman Sur, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and has two school-age children. Radisa is a farmer. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes from planting and harvesting corn. She has been engaged in this business for over 15 years. Every quarter, she earn 13,200 PHP from this cultivation. She has requested a loan of  5,000 PHP at GDMPC, which she will use to purchase corn seeds and fertilizers.

Radisa has been a member of GDMPC for six months. In the future, Radisa hopes to expand her corn production and purchase additional land for corn plantation.

loans.use: to purchase corn seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 51 years old, married, and has five children aged 5 to 25. She operates a small retail business selling maize, beans, perfumes, and other cosmetics. Gladys has been running this business for five years and employs one person. She intends to use her loan to purchase more maize and beans for sale. 

In the future, she hopes to expand her business into a wholesale one. She also hopes to buy a plot of land to build rental houses. Gladys describes herself as visionary.

loans.use: to purchase more maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is from Kapatagan, Lanao del Norte, Philippines. She is 35 years old and married. She has school-aged children to take care of. To answer her day to day needs, Rosalie has engaged in a buy and sell type of business venture. For 7 years she has been acquiring several kinds of bananas to sell in the local community and in neighboring communities. This became a big part of her daily routines and because of this she makes about PHP 7,000 a month.

In 2009, Rosalie became an official member of GDMPC. For the 3rd time around, she has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 from the cooperative to acquire several kinds of bananas to sell. She hopes to have enough revolving funds and to have enough business resources to maintain good sales.

loans.use: To acquire several kinds of bananas to sell.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a married woman with four children, two girls and two boys. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated a fried fish business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of purchasing a motor vehicle in the future. 

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes, cooking fat, wheat flour and tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of potatoes, cooking fat, wheat flour and tomatoes.

loans.name: G.s. Divino Niño Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario Llamado Divino Niño 10 está conformado por  Dolores Rosa Emelina. A pesar de las diversas actividades económicas que ellas tienen como es venta de cosméticos y bolsas plásticas,  tienen  el mismo objetivo de salir adelante porque sus negocios les han propiciado los estudios necesarios a sus hijos. Dolores  tiene más de 22 años de trabajar en el negocio ya que la mayoría de sus clientes siempre le están solicitando una gran variedad de productos. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de ropa en general, ropa interior, entre otros.
texts.en: The solidarity group called "Divine Child 10" is conformed by  Dolores and Rosa Emelina.  They have economic activities such as cosmetics and plastic bags, they have the same goal of getting ahead because their businesses have enabled them to provide for their children´s studies.  Dolores has worked for more than 22 years in the business, as most of her clients ask for a variety of products, the loan requested is to buy all types of clothing, including lingerie.

loans.use: to buy all types of clothing, including lingerie

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 45-year-old married lady. She runs a tailoring business in Mtopanga, Mombasa. She has been in this business for the last ten years. 
Mary has been a KADET client for quite some time now and this is her second loan to finance her business. With this loan she plans to purchase cloth and an extra sewing machine. The anticipated profits will be used to repay the loan and to gradually expand her business. Her dream is to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and an extra sewing machine.

loans.name: Gappor

texts.ru: Гаппор женат и любящий отец 2 детей. Он занимается откормом скота. Его жена занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур. В начале, когда Гаппор начинал свой бизнес, у него было 3 голов скота, а теперь у него бизнес расширился и в настоящее время он имеет 6 голов скота. А также Гаппор занимается выращиванием сельхоз культур. В этом бизнесе помогает ему его жена и дети. Гаппор хочет расширить свой бизнес и увеличить свой оборотный капитал. С этой целью он запрашивает займ в сумме 1200$ США.
texts.en: Gappor is married and a loving father of two children. He raises beef cattle for a living while his wife farms. At first Gappor only had three calves in his herd, but now his business has expanded and he has six calves. Gappor also helps his wife and children grow vegetables for the market. Gappor wants to expand his herd and requests a loan of 1200 US dollars.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida has completed her education to 8th standard and is a married lady. She operates a grocery store to supplement the income for her family. Her grocery store is very famous among the customers due to her quality products and reasonable prices. Her husband is a loader and operates a loading and unloading business. He has a donkey cart on which he loads goods and delivers to the designated places.

Zahida is the mother of three children: one daughter and two sons. Her daughter reads in 8th standard, her elder son is in 6th standard, and her younger son is in 5th standard.

Zahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her grocery store business. With the loan, she will buy groceries in bulk to stock her store. She is confident that with the increased stock she will increase her sales and earns better profits.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery store business.

loans.name: Bienestar Y Paz En Dios 2 Group

texts.en:
Ana is one of the members of the “Bienestar y Paz en Dios 2” (Prosperity and Peace in God ). They are micro entrepreneurs who sell clothing, assorted merchandise, shoes, crafts, etc. They sell mainly in the city of El Seybo, a farming community in the northeast of the country.

Ana makes her home in a simple structure with her husband and their five children. She tells us that her most difficult challenge has been raising her children. She enjoys attending church. 

Ana has been selling vegetables and clothes for about six years. She started the business selling just vegetables. Now, about five years after receiving her first loan from Esperanza Internacional, she is receiving her eighth, which she will invest to buy vegetables and various jeans, skirts, blouses and shirts. 

Ana will use the profits to save for her family’s future. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and clothes to resell.

loans.name: Pilika Group

texts.en:
Shaban, who is in his mid 30s, is married. Of his three children, two of them go to school. He has been operating a small store for four years now where he sells sugar, salt, rice, wheat flour, water, juice and paraffin. He works from 6 am to 6 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be his 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. Shaban used the previous loan to increase the stock of his business and has paid back his loan successfully.  He wants a loan to increase his stock.  His dream is to one day be able to own a big shamba.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Pilika" which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more water, juice, more kilos of sugar, rice, wheat flour paraffin and salt.

loans.name: Claudia Ester

texts.es:
CLAUDIA 
quien se dedica desde varios años a la venta de producto Onmilife medicina natural,  ahora es consejera y mayorista en el área de su comunidad donde ella vive,  es una señora con mucho entusiasmo y amor al trabajo y mas cuando sabe que gracias al aporte que  ella percibe a través de su negocio ha apoyado a su hija en sus estudios a quien desea que este año alcance su primer logro escolar en su nivel diversificado, ella  en su domicilio cuenta con su centro de apoyo para las demás personas  que venden este producto medicinal. Como también tiene una venta de tortillas de 3 tiempos, el estar en el negocio de las ventas de ONMILIFE le ha brindado conocer a muchas personas y recibir ciertos beneficios, logro recibir un curso de floristería con el cual ahora ella ofrece este servicio de preparar arreglos florales para diferentes ocasiones, siendo esto un ingreso mas para su bolsillo, y pueda desempeñar su papel como madre y pequeña  comerciante.esta solicitando este credito para la compra de medicina natural.
texts.en:
Claudia has been selling Omnilife (natural medicine) products for several years.  She is now a director and wholesaler in her community.  She is a lady with a lot of enthusiasm who loves her work.  She loves her work even more because she knows that, thanks to the contribution she makes through her business, she has supported her daughter in her studies.  This year she would like her daughter to enjoy her first educational success at high school.

At home, Claudia has a support center for other people who sell Omnilife medicinal products.  She also sells tortillas three times a day.  Through her Omnilife sales business, Claudia has gotten to know a lot of people and to reap some rewards.  She managed to take a course in flower-arranging and she now offers this service, preparing floral arrangements for different occasions.  This makes an additional income for her pocket and she is able to fulfill her role as a mother as well as her role as a small businesswoman.  Claudia is requesting this loan to buy natural medicines.

loans.use: to buy natural medicines to sell

loans.name: Claudette

texts.en:
Claudette is married with one child. Claudette is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Claudette is a farmer and raises pigs to earn a living. She has been doing this for three years. She has requested a loan of PHP 14,900 to purchase additional pigs to raise. 

Claudette has been a member of PMPC for five years. In the future, Claudette hopes to save money for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs to raise.

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.es:
María emprendedora, trabajadora, comerciante, casada, sus hijos estudiantes, su esposo le ayuda en el negocio. Sus planes son mejorar las condiciones infraestructurales de la vivienda y panadería ya que produce mayores cantidades en comparación al inicio y el espacio pequeño. La panadería es la fuente de ingreso para el hogar colocándose en el campo del comercio desde hace un tiempo. Se le ha presentado como dificultad que al producir más cantidades de pan, ella invierte la ganancia y no existe un fondo de capital que cubra la producción. Inicio por la necesidad de una fuente de ingreso al estar desempleado su esposo y ella, con el conocimiento en la elaboración de panes ellos tenía suficiente base para iniciar la panadería. Necesita el préstamo para construir una habitación destinada para el negocio así                       independizarlo de la casa y obtener mayores beneficios.  Comprara materiales de construcción como: cemento, bloques, ladrillos, arena, piedrín,  perlines, hierro, golosa, piedras cantera, alambré de amare,  laminas de zinc, verja, reglones de madera, pintura,  entre otros materiales. 
Agradece por el apoyo al desarrollo de su negocio mediante el financiamiento obtenido. Siendo de gran importancia para el cambio de su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Maria, a hardworking, enterprising businesswoman who is married, her children are students, and her husband helps her in her business.  Her plans are to improve the structure of her house and bakery since the she now produces more than when she started and the space is small.  The bakery is the source of income for the family and has given the family a business basis for a time now.  It’s been difficult to produce greater quantities of bread because she has used the earnings so now there is no working capital to cover the production.  She started the business as an income source when she and her husband were unemployed.  They knew how to bake bread so they had the basis to open a bakery.  She needs the loan for a building that will be separate from the house so that it will be more practical.  She will buy construction materials such as cement, blocks, brick, paint, gravel, purlines,  iron, boards, flagstone, construction wire, zinc laminated sheets, wrought iron, paint, etc.
She appreciates the support for her business with the financing since this is very important to change their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Tim, 36, is widowed and earns a living to support her family by making bathing scrubs. She lives with her son in Ho Chi Minh City. 

Tim started the business five years ago. She would like to take a loan to expand the business. With the loan she intends to increase her working capital by buying good materials that will enable her to make better-quality products for her customers. She hopes that this will generate more income and that she can save money for her child to go to school.

loans.use: To buy materials to make better-quality bathing scrubs.

loans.name: Morayma

texts.es: Morayma, de 22 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora, además de alegre y amable, esta separada de su pareja, pero vive en compañía de su madre y su hijo de 2 años de edad, instalados cómodamente en la casa de su madre. El negocio que tiene Morayma es la venta de golosinas la cual realiza en el frontis de su casa, instalando un tablero donde exhibe sus productos. Éste negocio se inició por iniciativa propia y con un préstamo de su hermana hace 01 año atrás. Paralelo a ello, también vende comida en sociedad con su madre, principalmente menú, para eso cuentan con un espacio acondicionado en el frontis de su casa junto con su venta de golosinas, y los domingos venden parrilla de pollo, realizando éste negocio ya hace 5 años. Le gusta lo que hace ya que la mantiene activa, y le permiten tener un ingreso económico para poder solventar los gastos de su hijo que es su mayor motivación. Al contario comenta que le incomoda de su negocio el tener que levantarse de madrugada para empezar con las actividades de su negocio, pero viendo el buen resultado que tienen y las buenas ganancias que les deja, desea continuar con su negocio y ampliar con la venta de bebida gaseosa, para eso ya cuenta con una refrigeradora. Este será el préstamo número 2 con la institución MFP, comenta sentirse agradecida con el apoyo financiero para avanzar con su negocio. Además de sentirse bien con su banco comunal pues considera a sus integrantes ser personas responsables y solidarias. Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles lo invertirá en la compra de bebidas gaseosas al por mayor, para ofrecer a sus clientes y acompañen aen la comida.
texts.en: Morayma, 22, is an enterprising woman, hard-working, happy and welcoming.  She is separated from her husband and lives with her mother and 2-year old son.  She operates a snacks business in a space just outside her mother's front door.  She started the business a year ago with money she borrowed from her sister.  She and her mother also sell prepared meals.  They have a purpose-built stand in front of the house from which they sell the meals and they set up a grill on Sundays to make and sell grilled chicken.  That business has been up and running for 5 years.  Morayma likes the business because it gives her something to do and brings in the income she needs to support her son.  The hardest thing about the business, she says, is getting up at dawn to organize the day's work.  She's not complaining, though, because she sees that her income has grown along with her efforts and she wants to continue the business and grow it.  She wants to sell soft drinks with the snacks she sells and she needs a refrigerator to start.  This will be her second MFP loan and she tells us that she is grateful for the help she's received to grow her business.  She likes her community bank, too, and says that its members are responsible and supportive.  Morayma will use this 1000 new soles loan to buy wholesale supplies of soft drinks for her food business.

loans.use: to stock her food business.

loans.name: Dominador

texts.en: Dominador, who is 51 years old, lives with his partner. He has two children. Dominador lives in his own house and tries very hard to provide a better life for his children. He works as a farmer, where he cultivates crops plants. He works very hard on the farming field. He has been working for 23 years on his own land. During the planting season, he counts on the support of his children and day laborers who see to the planting and move the collected products to a certain place so that later in can be transported with small vehicles. He feels very dedicated to his work. Thanks to his daily effort, today he enjoys seeing his plants give him a good crop. He says that he does not like the winter season because there is a large quantity of insects and rain during those months, damaging his crops. With the loan that he is asking for, he will buy more seed and fertilizer to expand his sown fields. With the P 15,000 he will buy seed,chemical and fertilizer products to maintain his crops.

loans.use: to buy chemical, fertilizer and seed to grow for his farming business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel lives in the Litein area of Kenya, which is home to a campus of Mt. Kenya University. He has four children and has been doing this work for nine years. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, and tea. He stated what is most enjoyable about farming as: “Juhudi's loan meetings” His biggest challenge is “Ploughing land.” Animals on the farm have been given the names of “Tin.” Daniel was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: “Good client relations.” This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session: “Asset financing.” His highest monthly expense is for school fees. When asked “How this loan would benefit his family”, Daniel replied “Basic needs will be more available.” As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Daniel owns the following: “cow, poultry” but does not own “pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile”. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household “mosquito net, TV” but does not have “electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, DVD”.

loans.use: to construct a zero-grazing pen.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman. She has 4 children. She describes herself to be committed. She operates a retail business where she sells flour, sugar, salt, juices and other items. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of flour, sugar, salt and other items. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy more stock of flour, sugar, salt and other items

loans.name: Maari

texts.en:
Maari is married with 6 children. Maari has been greatly empowered through her active participation in various development activities. She is the coordinator of her village focal group. WEEC organized a training on Modern methods of livestock management, and she was among the participants.

In year 2004 Maari joined WEEC credit programme and was given a loan of USD 60. Her loan went to buy her first steer. To pay up her loan she started making bead ornaments for sale. This and the sale of milk enabled her to pay her loan promptly. After the fattening period, Maari sold the steers at the local market for USD 120.This enabled her to buy two Small steers. The steers are in the fattening period and will be sold in three months time.

loans.use: A loan of USD 450 Will help Maari to buy seven small steers. In three months, she will be able to get good profits and thus improve her standard of living.

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en:
This 51-year-old man is a very hard-working person, married, has 4 children, lives in Fizuli region Bala Behmenli village.
In the beginning  of his business he borrowed a loan of $400 and bought armature and iron sheets.
The second  loan of $800 he spent to buy iron materials to start manufacturing iron gratings, iron doors.
He manufactures and repaires the iron constructions: iron doors, windows, tanks, gratings.
Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy welding apparatus. He plans to buy the apparatus for cutting and hewing irons.

loans.use: To buy equipments

loans.name: Florencio David

texts.en:
Florencio sells perfumes and his working method is quite different; he does not have a store, but goes door to door selling his products. This is how he got his clients. Florencio says "I would like t continue improving and get more clients so my business can grow, and to this purpose, I would like to ask for a $1,200 loan."

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Don Florencio se dedica a la venta de perfumes su forma de trabajar es muy particular ya que no tiene un lugar fijo sino que los va ofreciendo de casa en casa, así ha formado su cartera de clientes. "Mi interés es seguir progresando y acumular mas clientes para que mi negocio salga a flote, solicito un crédito de $1,200.00 dlls".

loans.use: Para comprar mercancía (perfumes)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve his store and buy spare parts for bicycle repair.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Mrs. Hong S. is a 43-year-old mother of five children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She sells grocery products to the people in her area, where earns her on average $3/day of income. Her husband and two of her children make ice-cream and sell it at different places in their community. Together, they make up to $8 each day. The rest of her children attend school. This loan will be beneficially used to purchase a motorcycle and a cart, which will enable one of her children to sell ice-cream to make additional income for their family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and a cart to sell ice-cream.

loans.name: Filda

texts.en:
Filda A. is an active member of Life in Africa Foundation. She is originally from Northern Uganda but was forced to leave her home due to Kony's insurgency. She is a married woman aged 45 with seven children, and they all live in the IDP camp in Kampala known as the Acholi Quarters.

Filda is working in a stone quarry where she earns just enough money to sustain her family but this is not really enough to support seven children. Filda has a good plan to start a business buying and selling groundnuts (peanuts). They are a favorite of Acholis and are always in high demand. She plans to grind some and sell some whole to those who may need them. She expects a profit of 50,000/= (the symbol /= means Uganda shillings here; about US $ 28) per month.

To start up this business Filda is requesting a loan in the amount of 250,000/= (US$ 150). Once given this loan, she feels sure she will be able to repay it in 6 months.

Below is her breakdown:

200 kilograms of groundnuts ……………….200, 000/=

Transport……………………………………….20, 000/=

Grinding…………………………………………30,000/=

Total……………………………………………..250,000/=

loans.use: Buying and selling groundnuts (peanuts)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy  plastic chairs, tables, and other equipment

loans.name: Tamam

texts.en:
Tamam (her husband is pictured) was born in 1967. She is the mother of 2 children. Her husband has been as a taxi driver for 5 years. Tamam and her family live in the  Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Now Tamam needs a loan of $725 to buy spare parts for her family's taxi to  improve their business. 

Note: Tamam's husband is pictured as Tamam did not want to be photographed for cultural reasons.

loans.use: to buy spare car parts

loans.name: Ciro César

texts.es:
Ciro César M. M. is a married man and father of three children. This man's business is a corner store, and since he was very young he worked hard to support his household. The corner store business started 12 years ago with only a small nunber of items but with the passage of time he has been improving the business.

He tells us that all of his life he has been an agriculturist, but that type of work wasn't yielding enough income to be able to establish himself financially, but there was a turning point when he decided to establish his corner store in the main market of Chichigalpa.

Mr. Ciro Cesar works with CEPRODEL for 4 years now and he feels very satisfied with the timely credits that have been granted to him, helping him to fill the business' needs and fill the needs of his household. He has a history of 19 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Ciro César M. M., es un señor casado y con 3 hijos que mantener. El negocio de este señor es una pulpería, desde muy joven ha trabajado fuertemente por llevar el sustento a su hogar. El negocio de la pulpería lo comienza hace 12 años con pequeñas cantidades de productos pero a medida que el tiempo ha transcurrido ha venido mejorando su condición del negocio. El nos comenta que toda su vida ha sido agricultor, pero que este tipo de negocio no le generaba ingresos suficientes como para poder desarrollarse económicamente, por lo que este también fue un elemento para decidirse a establecer su pulpería en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa. Don Ciro César trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy satisfecho con los créditos otorgados pues se los han brindado en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer las necesidades del su casa, el tiene un record de 19 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Mkama's Mena Group

texts.en:
Mkama J. W., age 43, is married and has 2 children (ages 12 and 6). He has a clothing business, which he began 8 years ago. He works from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM daily, and he has been able to make a monthly profit of about US$34.

Mkama has taken out 1 previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his clothing business. He hopes to receive a new loan for further business expansion. Mkama will share this loan with his subgroup members, who have businesses in the sale of general store items, clothes, and furniture.

In the picture Mkama is in the middle of the back row.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria O. is 28years old and lives in Benin City, Edo State. She sells general provisions and she expects an increase in demand.  Therefore, Gloria needs a loan of $900 to buy more provisions in bulk, which  she says will enable her to better satisfy her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Rosa Perputua

texts.es:
Rosa Perpetua L. T. is 48 years of age and completed her studies up to middle school. She has 6 children, but only one depends on her. She lives in the Salaverry district in the Trujillo province in La Libertad, Perú.

Rosa started her business when a group of teachers gave a workshop to a group of mothers in their sector. There, she learned how to create lingerie and sportswear. With time, her work has become well-known and her neighbors and relatives place several orders.

She is a member of the communal bank “JERID – Camino al Éxito” (Path to Success). With her previous loan, she was able to create various garments and holiday ornaments, thus taking advantage of the campaign which she has done very well with.

With the loan of S/. 1000.00, which she will repay in six months, she will purchase spun polyester, spandex and other materials used to create winter clothing being that it is right around the corner.

She is very happy with her business because the earnings have allowed her to complete the construction of her home.

Rosa is the president of the Mother’s Club ““Purísima Concepción” (Immaculate Conception). Her greatest wish is to purchase a mending machine to provide a more sophisticated finish to her garments.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa Perpetua L. T. tiene 48 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa. Tiene 6 hijos pero solo 1 depende de ella. Vive en el distrito de Salaverry provincia de Trujillo en el Departamento de La Libertad – Perú.

La señora Rosa inicia su negocio cuando un grupo de maestros fueron a enseñar al club de madres de su sector, allí aprendió a confeccionar lencería y ropa deportiva. Con el tiempo se ha hecho muy conocida, le hacen varios pedidos sus vecinas y sus familiares.

Es socia del Banco Comunal “JERID – Camino al Éxito” con el anterior préstamo que recibió pudo confeccionar varias prendas y adornos navideños de esa manera aprovecho la campaña la cual le ha ido muy bien.

Con el préstamo de S/.1000.00 que cancelará en seis meses comprará tela polar, tela alicrada y otros materiales para confeccionar ropa de invierno ya que se aproxima.

Está muy contenta con su negocio porque con lo que le permite ganar a terminado de construir su casa.

La señora Rosa es presidenta del club de madres “Purísima Concepción”.Su mayor sueño es comprar una remalladota para dar mejor acabado a sus confecciones.

loans.use: Purchase prime materials to create winter clothing.

loans.name: Ablavi  Agbéko

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ablavi Agbéko K. was born in 1983 in Lomé and left primary school because of lack of financial means. She began the business of selling corn and manages to participate in household expenses because of the income from her business. A real go-getter, she managed her first loan without trouble. Now she is requesting a loan that will permit her to strengthen her business by buying in large quantities. This will allow her to satisfy her customers' needs and increase her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame K. Ablavi Agbéko est née en 1983 à Lomé et a arrêté ses études primaires par manque de moyens. Elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de la vente de maïs, et arrive à participer aux charges du foyer par les revenus de son activité. Très battante, elle a su bien gérer le premier crédit sans incident. A présent, elle sollicite un crédit qui lui servira à renforcer son activité en achetant en grande quantité. Ceci lui permettra de satisfaire sa clientèle et d’accroître ses revenus.

loans.use:
buying and selling corn

Achat et vente de mais

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Since 2000,  Prum T. has had a business selling a variety of vegetables in a busy market. She brings vegetables from the farm and resells them at the market. She typically makes around $3.50 each day. Her husband is a construction worker building houses and he is also a farmer. On average he makes $1.50 each day. This couple has five children, two who are students and one is employed as a garment worker.

The family would like a loan to purchase wood to repair their leaking roof. This will provide them a stable house. (husband is pictured at the farmland)

loans.use: They hope to use this loan to repair their leaking roof.

loans.name: Rima

texts.ru:
Rima K. lives in the Gissar district. She is 45 years old and unmarried, and has a university degree in agronomy. Rima buys and sells fruits and vegetables.
